Award.AwardTitle: ENGAGE: A Game-based Curricular Strategy for Infusing Computational Thinking into Middle School Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains. Building on a previously developed and tested prototype for computer science education in a middle school oceanography elective, the ENGAGE project's objective is to design and study a more comprehensive curricular strategy for middle school life science using a game-based learning environment that will deeply integrate computational thinking practices within the life science curriculum. Topics will include the study of interdependent relationships of species in ecosystems, matter and energy in organisms and ecosystems, and natural selection of species and their adaptations for survival. Along with a focus on student learning, the project will develop and study a teacher professional development model to support teachers in the integration of computational thinking in middle school life science. Principal Investigators will gather specific evidence about the ways in which game-based learning can effectively support computationally rich science practices aligned with the new Science Education Framework (National Research Council, 2012) and the Computer Science Teachers' Association, Computer Science Education Computational Thinking Framework (2016). Specifically, the effort will: (1) design an innovative curricular strategy and novel game-based learning environment to develop computationally rich science practices (developing and using models, and analyzing and interpreting data), for middle school students from North Carolina and Florida; (2) investigate how middle school students develop computational thinking practices (creating abstractions and models, analyzing problems and artifacts, and developing computational artifacts) in middle school science classrooms with the game-based learning environment; and (3) develop an evidence-based teacher professional development program that supports teachers in the deep integration of computational thinking into middle grades science.

The overarching research question will be: How can deep, mastery-oriented gameplay develop core computational thinking practices in middle school life science? Related sub-questions will include: (a) How can game-based learning promote the development of students' science and engineering practices?; (b) How can game-based learning promote student mastery of computational thinking deeply infused science education?; and (c) How can game-based learning for computationally rich science improve students' attitudes in science with regard to short-term self-efficacy, outcome expectancy, and long-term STEM career interest? The project will undertake three types of activities carried out in parallel across each year of the project. First, it will develop and iteratively refine the curricular strategy and collaborative game-based learning environment, which will be implemented at partner middle schools in North Carolina and Florida, with increasing numbers of teachers and students participating in each succeeding year. Second, the study will develop, implement, and refine the corresponding professional development materials and associated online and face-to-face activities. The teacher professional development will be implemented throughout the school year, utilizing both a summer institute and ongoing school-based support. Third, classroom studies will be conducted to build the evidence base on how middle school students can most effectively develop computationally rich science practices. For the classroom studies, the project will compare three conditions: (1) the baseline condition (standard science classroom practice with no project implementation) will utilize teachers who have not previously participated in the project; (2) the project-without-game condition, where students will participate in an implementation of the curricular strategy that provides out-of-game computational problem solving on data-rich science problems outside of the game, but does not provide the game-based learning experiences; and (3) implementation of a full version of the ENGAGE curricular strategy that provides both game-based learning experiences, as well as outside-of-game computational problem solving. Data-gathering strategies throughout the three-year duration of the study will include: classroom observations, individual teacher interviews, student and teacher focus groups, project-developed assessments, embedded game-based learning assessments, student-created artifact assessments, pre- and posttest assessments, and assessments of science and STEM attitudes. Data interpretation strategies will include: comparative analysis of scores across years and across the three experimental conditions, observational and formative analyses to guide refinement of learning tasks, qualitative and quantitative analyses of student performance and growth, and formative analysis of changes in self-reported attitudes. The main outcome of the project will be a research-informed and field-tested prototype integrating computational thinking into science learning at the middle school level. An external organization will conduct the formative and summative evaluations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building upon science standards and emerging computer science curricula, and leveraging significant advances in game-based learning, the overarching goal of the Engage project was to deeply infuse computational thinking into middle school science education.

The project made significant contributions in the following areas:

1) We iteratively designed, developed, and refined an innovative set of curricular materials and strategy that were piloted and tested in middle school classrooms of 44 teachers over the course of the project. The design of the Engage computationally rich game-based learning environment for middle grades computer science education and computational thinking was informed by core computer science (CS) concepts and practices delineated in the K-12 Computer Science Framework as well as focal knowledge, skills, and abilities for middle-grade CS education highlighted by Grover & Basu (2017). In parallel, we developed a series of computational modeling activities that effectively complement game-based learning with a middle grades science curricular strategy that seamlessly integrates science problem solving and computation. Over the course of the project, a diverse set of 3,464 middle school students at 12 different partner schools in North Carolina, Florida, and Texas have used the Engage curricular materials. The majority of these students are from groups that have been historically underserved and underrepresented within STEM domains.

2) Through the Engage game-based learning environment, which situates computationally rich science problem solving in interactive narratives, we investigated how game-based learning and modeling activities can motivate students to solve challenging science problems and acquire the standards-based science and engineering practices centered on computer science and computational thinking. Results from classroom studies in these schools demonstrated that students learned important computer science and computational thinking concepts, as well as computational problem-solving strategies, while engaging with the learning environment and curricular materials. These studies also informed how students advance their learning of CS and science topics, and make a connection between these two disciplines, as well as demonstrated that computational modeling in science classrooms can increase student motivation to learn computational thinking and science. A culminating study with the Engage game-based learning environment revealed that all students, regardless of prior programming experience, showed significant learning gains from pre to post after interacting with the game (t = 2.06, p = .045). Additionally, students' qualitative data revealed that the Use-Modify-Create scaffolding progression embedded within the game design provided students, particularly those with little to no prior programming experience, with the foundational knowledge needed to progress through the game levels and challenges.

3) The research team designed and validated novel assessment instruments and techniques for measuring middle grades students' competencies and attitudes towards computer science. Through a broad range of computational approaches to modeling students' interactions with the learning environment, we investigated a high-fidelity stealth assessment framework to automatically assess students' computer science competencies in a non-intrusive manner using multiple channels of game trace data, such as low-level game interaction logs and programming artifacts. Robust modeling of student learning via stealth assessment holds significant potential to inform effective pedagogical strategies for creating student-adaptive CS learning experiences while promoting students' engagement during game-based learning activities. Additionally, the project team developed and validated an instrument to measure middle grades students' knowledge of computer science concepts (MG-CSCA) and attitudes towards computer science (MG-CS Attitudes). Using these instruments, we also determined important relationships between middle grades students' prior programming and attitudes on computer science learning and gender, which together were used to inform the developments of our curricular strategy.  

4) The project supported the collaboration of 44 teachers in North Carolina, Florida, and Texas who have benefitted from Engage and its associated professional development program. We have showcased the Engage curricular strategy through workshops in North Carolina, Florida, and Texas throughout the course of the project. We also provided intensive professional development situated within teachers' classrooms which led to a faded scaffolding professional development model for the integration of computational modeling within science classrooms. These collaborative efforts have led to a greater understanding of the support that teachers need to successfully facilitate students' computationally rich problem solving. We will continue to promote and support teachers' integration efforts of the Engage curricular materials through our Engage project website which allows teachers to access the curricular content and support guides.

5) We have disseminated research findings from the Engage project with scholars and practitioners through numerous publications, presentations, and workshops. To date the findings of the project have been reported in 6 journal articles (five published and one in press), 12 conference papers, 2 workshop papers, and 13 presentations at conferences for both researchers and practitioners. Findings from this set of published work will guide future research and development on engaging, effective curricular strategies for middle grades computer science and computational thinking.
